trial_identification.studytitle: Evaluation of a couple-based program for promoting a positive transition to parenthood
trial_identification.scientifictitle: A randomised controlled trial of the effects of Couple CARE (a couple-based program) for couples having their first child on couple relationship adjustment, individual partner mood and parenting competence.

conditioncode.conditioncode2: Studies of normal psychology, cognitive function and behaviour

interventions.interventions: Couples are randomly allocated to either six 1-hour sessions (one per month until child is three months old) of a couple-focused psycho-education program entitiled 'Couple CARE for Parents'(CCP). Both programs are offered to couples expecting their first baby and continue until their first child is three months old.
interventions.comparator: Couples are randomly allocated to five 1-hour sessions (held monthly until child is three months old) of a mother-focused information and support program.

primaryOutcome.outcome: Couple relationship satisfaction (DAS). Couple seperation and divorce. Couple aggression (CTS2). Observed couple communication. Couple self-regulation (SRERS).
primaryOutcome.timepoint: Follow-up assessments at 1 and 2 years post-partum.
Follow-up assessments at 1 and 2 years post-partum.
Follow-up assessments at 1 and 2 years post-partum.
Follow-up assessments at 1 and 2 years post-partum.
Follow-up assessments at 1 and 2 years post-partum.

secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Follow-up assessments at 1 and 2 years post-partum.
Follow-up assessments at 1 and 2 years post-partum.

Follow-up assessments at 1 and 2 years post-partum.

eligibility.inclusivecriteria: Couples are eligible if they are a. married or in a cohabiting heterosexual relationship of duration 6 months or longer; b.have a Dyadic Adjustment Scale score of 90 or above indicting no severe relationship distress; c. expecting thier first live born child.
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: (a) neither partner reports severe physical aggression or frequent less severe physical aggression have occured in the last 12 months, (b) neither partner is currently receiving treatment for a psychological disorder or for a couple relationship problem.

trial_design.concealment: Random allocation occurs in a central office by research staff who are not involved in participant assessment or program delivery . Allocation is kept in a sealed envelope and concealed from couples, the researcher determing study eligibility, and midwife educators until all assessment information is returned and the couple meets eligibility criteria. After that point allocation concealement is no longer possible as one condition is a couple based education porgam and the other a woman only education condition.
trial_design.sequence: A coin toss determines the allocation for a couple (heads = intervention), and the next couple who returns their assessment receives the opposite allocation. This ensures that equal numbers of couples are assignment to the intervention and control. The coin toss procedure is repeated until all couples are assigned.

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: Mt Gravatt Campus School of Psychology Griffith University

fundingsource.fundingaddress: MDP P33 GPO box 9848 Canberra ACT 2601

ethicsAndSummary.summary: The aim of the study is to test the effects of a couple based education program (Couple CARE for Parents) with couples having their first baby. We will assign couples to receive Couple CARE for Parents or usual woman focused education and support. We predict that Couple CARE for Parents will enhance couple relationship satisfaction, individual adjustment and parenting.
